page.title: Siege of Tyre (332 BC)

infobox.caption: the siege of tyre.
infobox.map_caption: location of the siege of tyre
infobox.result: [[macedonia (ancient kingdom)|macedonian]] victory<ref>"philip was born a greek of the most aristocratic, indeed of divine, descent... philip was both a greek and a macedonian, even as demosthenes was a greek and an athenian...", ''[[nicholas hammond]], "philip of macedon" (duckworth publishing, february 1998)''</ref><ref>"...for the first time he (phillip) started to understand how macedonia's outdated institutions of feudalism an aristocratic monarchy so despised by the rest of greece", ''[[peter green (historian)|peter green]], "alexander the great", page 24''</ref><ref>"such a glorious ancestry was in the eyes of greeks the hallmark of '''the hellenic persona of the king of macedon''', who could, on the other hand, rely on fidelity of the people from which he had sprung. the greek cities did not feel that they were allying with a barbarian, since for generations the macedonian dynasty had been allowed, '''as greeks''', to take part in the olympic games. ''[[françois chamoux]], "hellenistic civilization", (blackwell publishing professional, 2002, p.8, 9)</ref><ref>"'''the macedonians were greeks. their language was greek''', to judge by their personal names and by the names of the months of the calendar; macedonian ambassadors could appear before the athenian assembly without needing interpreters; in all demosthenes' sneers about their civilization '''there is no hint that macedonians spoke other than greek'''"  ("philip of macedon", faber & faber, london, 1978, p. 22), [[george cawkwell]], emeritus fellow, [[university college oxford|oxford university college]]''</ref><ref>"philip ii, at least from the time of his victory over phocis, athens, and their allies in 346, prepared to proclaim himself the champion of '''a united greece''' against the barbarians", ''[[ernst badian]], "cambridge history of iran", p. 421''</ref><ref>"...'''the macedonians''', our conviction is strengthened that '''they were a greek race and akin to the dorians'''. having stayed behind in the extreme north, they were unable to participate in the progressive civilization of the tribes which went further south...", [[ulrich wilcken]], "alexander the great", p. 22''</ref><ref>"to his ancestors (to a persian's ancestors) macedonians were only known as 'yona takabara', the 'greeks who wear shields on their heads', an allusion to their broad-brimmed hats", [[robin lane fox]], "alexander the great", p.104''</ref><ref>"it was the byzantine empire, which was '''to realize alexander's idea - macedonian panhellenism -'''in face of an asia in revolt, and realize it for the '''greeks'''. ''[[rené grousset]], a. patterson, "the sum of history", p. 159''.</ref><ref>"...king philip of '''the northern greek kingdom of macedon''' perfected this system, and his son, alexander the great...", ''archer jones, american historian, "the art of war in western world" (university of illinois press, 2000), p. 21''</ref>
infobox.casualties2: 6,000–7,000 killed in action<br/>2,000 executed<ref>Arrian Anabasis 2.24.4; Diodorus Library 17.46.4 claims 7,000, with 2,000 having been crucified; Quintus Curtius 4.4.16 claims 6,000, with 2,000 having been crucified on the beach</ref><br>13,000–30,000 civilians enslaved<ref>Arrian Anabasis 2.24.5; Diodorus 17.46.4 claims 13,000</ref>

links: File:Alexander the Great in the Siege of Tyre.jpg
File:A naval action during the siege of Tyre by Andre Castaigne (1898-1899).jpg

page.title: Battle of the Granicus

infobox.image: charles le brun, le passage du granique, 1665.png
infobox.caption: the battle of the granicus river<br/>by [[charles le brun]]
infobox.map_caption: location of the battle of granicus.
infobox.place: granicus river, [[troad]] region, [[hellespontine phrygia]], [[achaemenid empire]] (modern-day [[biga çayı]], [[turkey]])
infobox.territory: alexander attains half of asia minor
infobox.combatant2:
[[image:standard of cyrus the great (achaemenid empire).svg|25px|achaemenid empire]] [[achaemenid empire]]
*satrapies of asia minor
infobox.commander1: '''[[alexander the great]]'''<br>[[parmenion]]<br>[[cleitus the black]]<br>[[hephaestion]]<br>[[calas (general)|calas]]<br>[[hegelochus of macedon|hegelochus]]<br>[[ptolemy (son of philip)|ptolemy]]
infobox.strength1: 32,000 [[infantry]] (12,000 macedonians, 5,000 mercenaries, 7,000 greeks, 7,000 odrysians, triballians and illyrians, and 1,000 archers)<br>5,100 cavalry (1,800 macedonians, 1,800 thessalians, 600 other greeks, and 900 thracians and paeonians)<br>'''total: 37,100'''
infobox.strength2: 10,000–20,000 [[cavalry]]<ref name=welman2>welman estimates the persian army to be 25,000 in total, including 10,000 cavalry and 5,000 greeks. fuller (1960) estimates 15,000 in total. delbrück (1920) estimates as low as 6,000 in total.</ref><ref name=arrian1>{{cite web|url=https://en.m.wikisource.org/wiki/the_anabasis_of_alexander/book_i/chapter_xiv#43|title=anabasis, book 1, chapter 14, section 4|last=arrian|first=|date=|website=en.m.wikisource.org|quote=''the persian cavalry were about 20,000 in number, and their infantry, consisting of grecian mercenaries, fell a little short of the same number.'' (translated by e. j. chinnock)}}</ref><br>5,000–20,000 greek [[hoplite]] mercenaries<ref name=welman2/><ref name=arrian1/><br>'''total: 20,000–30,000'''<ref>{{cite book |last1=clark |first1=jessica h. |last2=turner |first2=brian |title=brill’s companion to military defeat in ancient mediterranean society |date=2017 |publisher=brill |isbn=9789004355774 |page=78 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=girxdwaaqbaj&vq |accessdate=30 august 2019 |language=en}}</ref> (modern estimate)
infobox.casualties1: 300 to 400 killed<ref name=arrian>arrian in describing another battle considers that the proportion of twelve to one between wounded and killed is above what could have been expected (5.24.5). riiatow and kbchly (p. 27) state that in modern battles the ordinary proportion of wounded to killed is from 8:1 to 10:1. a total number of 115 is given as killed and 10 times of that for the wounded by {{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=31chaaaamaaj&dq=companion+cavalry&pg=pa317&ci=75,1394,426,220&source=bookclip |title=a history of greece from the earliest period to the close of the generation contemporary with alexander the great |first=george |last=grote}}</ref><br>1,150–1,380 to 3,500–4,200  wounded<ref name="arrian"/>
infobox.casualties2: 3,000 infantry killed<ref name="Arrian 1.16.45 - 50">Arrian 1.16.45 – 50</ref><br> 1,000 cavalry killed<ref name="Arrian 1.16.45 - 50"/><br>2,000 captured<ref name="Arrian 1.16.45 - 50"/>

links: Image:Standard of Cyrus the Great (Achaemenid Empire).svg
File:Spithridates attacking Alexander from behind at the Battle of Granicus.jpg

page.title: Battle of Issus

infobox.image: battle of issus mosaic - museo archeologico nazionale - naples.jpg
infobox.caption: alexander battling darius at the battle of issus ([[naples national archaeological museum]])
infobox.map_caption: location of the battle of issus
infobox.combatant1: [[file:vergina sun - golden larnax.png|25px]] [[macedonia (ancient kingdom)|macedon]]<br>[[league of corinth]]
infobox.combatant2: [[file:standard of cyrus the great (achaemenid empire).svg|25px]] [[achaemenid empire]]
infobox.strength1: 13,000 [[peltast]]s,<ref>warry (1998) estimates alexander's army to be 31,000 in total.{{page needed|date=september 2010}}</ref><br>22,000 heavy infantry,<ref name=moerbeek>moerbeek (1997).{{page needed|date=september 2010}}</ref><br>5,850 [[cavalry]]<ref name=moerbeek/><br>'''total: 40,850'''
infobox.strength2:
30,000–80,000 light infantry (babylonian spears, ionian peltasts)<ref name="battle of issus (pothos.org)">{{cite web|url=http://www.pothos.org/content/index.php?page=major-battles#issus|title=pothos.org - major battles|accessdate=19 august 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016165147/http://pothos.org/content/index.php?page=major-battles#issus|archivedate=16 october 2007}}</ref><br>11,000 cavalry<ref name="moerbeek"/><br>10,000 [[persian immortals]]<br>10,000 greek mercenaries<ref name=welman>welman.</ref><br>
'''total: 50,000–60,000'''<ref>{{cite book |last1=clark |first1=jessica h. |last2=turner |first2=brian |title=brill’s companion to military defeat in ancient mediterranean society |date=2017 |publisher=brill |isbn=9789004355774 |page=78 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=girxdwaaqbaj&vq |accessdate=30 august 2019 |language=en}}</ref> (modern sources)<br>'''250,000–600,000''' (ancient sources)
infobox.casualties1: 452 casualties<br>5,000 wounded<ref>curtius rufus also tells that, except for about 4,500 wounded, 150 macedonians were killed in action, and 302 were missing. this means that the army had lost about one tenth of its strength.</ref><ref name=hn/>
infobox.casualties2: ~20,000-40,000 casualties<ref name=hn>{{cite web|url=https://www.historynet.com/battle-of-gaugamela-alexander-versus-darius.htm|title=battle of gaugamela: alexander versus darius|website=[[historynet]]|author=barry potter|date=september 30, 2018|accessdate=august 18, 2019}}</ref>

page.title: Battle of Gaugamela

infobox.image: file:scene of the battle of arbela.jpg
infobox.caption: scene of the battle of gaugamela (also called "battle of arbela"). engraving from 1913
infobox.map_caption: location of the battle of gaugamela
infobox.place: probably tel gomel (gaugamela) near [[erbil]], modern [[iraqi kurdistan]]
infobox.territory: alexander gains babylon, half of persia and all other parts of mesopotamia
infobox.result: decisive macedonian victory <!-- do not alter the field 'result' before discussisng it with other users at the talk page  -->
infobox.combatant2: [[image:standard of cyrus the great (achaemenid empire).svg|25px|achaemenid empire]] [[achaemenid empire]]
infobox.commander1: '''[[alexander the great]]'''<br> [[hephaestion]]<br />[[craterus]] <br />[[parmenion]]<br />[[ptolemy i soter|ptolemy]]<br />[[perdiccas]]<br />[[antigonus i monophthalmus|antigonus]]<br />[[cleitus the black|cleitus]]<br />[[nearchus]]<br />[[seleucus i nicator|seleucus]]<br>[[ariston of paionia|ariston]]<br>[[simmias of macedon|simmias]]<br>[[coenus (general)|coenus]]<br>[[ariston of macedon|ariston]]<br>[[glaucias of macedon|glaucias]]<br>[[sopolis of macedon|sopolis]]
infobox.strength1:
47,000<ref name="green, peter 2013 p.288"/>
(see [[#size of macedonian army|size of macedonian army]])
infobox.casualties1: 100 [[infantry]] and 1,000 [[cavalry]] <br>(according to [[arrian]]); <br>300 infantry <br>(according to [[quintus curtius rufus|curtius rufus]]); <br>500 infantry <br>(according to [[diodorus siculus]])
infobox.casualties2: 40,000 <br>(according to [[quintus curtius rufus|curtius rufus]]) <br>47,000 <br>(according to welman)<ref name=welman/><br>90,000 <br>(according to [[diodorus siculus]]) <br>300,000+ captured <br>(according to [[arrian]]){{sfn|arrian|1893}}

infobox.strength1: 17,000 picked fighters<ref>http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/ariobarzanes-greek-form-of-old-iranian-proper-name-arya-brzana</ref><ref>d. w. engels: ''alexander the great and the logistics of the macedonian army'', university of california press, berkeley and london, 1978, {{isbn|0-520-04272-7}}, pp. 72f. (fn. 7)</ref><br> more than 14,000
infobox.strength2:
700<ref>[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/ariobarzanes-greek-form-of-old-iranian-proper-name-arya-brzana "ariobarzanes"]</ref><ref>bill yenne: "alexander the great: lessons from history's undefeated general", st. martin's press, new york, 2010, pp. 90</ref><ref> cais "the battle of the persian gate and the martyrdom of general ariobarzan and his defending regiment"</ref>
25,000 (curtius and diodorus)<br>40,000 (arrian)

page.title: Battle of the Hydaspes

infobox.image: [[image:the phalanx attacking the centre in the battle of the hydaspes by andre castaigne (1898-1899).jpg|250px]]
infobox.caption: a painting by [[andre castaigne]] depicting the [[phalanx formation|phalanx]] attacking the centre at hydaspes
infobox.territory: macedonian empire annexes large areas of the [[punjab region]] from the [[jhelum river|hydaspes]] to the [[beas river|hyphasis]].<ref name="books.google.co.in"/><ref>''"accordingly, alexander not only permitted him to govern his former kingdom, giving him the title of satrap, but also added to it the territory of the independent peoples whom he subdued, in which there are said to have been fifteen nations, five thousand cities of considerable size, and a great multitude of villages."'' plutarch's life of alexander 60.10</ref>
infobox.combatant1: [[macedonia (ancient kingdom)|macedon]]<br>[[league of corinth|hellenic league]]<br>[[achaemenid empire|persian]] allies <br>[[history of india|indian]] allies
infobox.strength1: 40,000 [[infantry]],<br>5,000<ref name="arrian 5.14"/> to 7,000<ref>fuller estimates a further 2,000 cavalry under craterus' command.</ref> [[cavalry]],<br>asiatic contingents<ref>harbottle, thomas benfield (1906). ''dictionary of battles''. new york.</ref>
infobox.strength2:
20,000,<ref name=plutarch621>plutarch 62.1:
<br>{{quote|"but this last combat with porus took off the edge of the [[ancient macedonians|macedonian]]s' courage, and stayed their further progress into india. for having found it hard enough to defeat an enemy who brought but twenty thousand foot and two thousand horse into the field, they thought they had reason to oppose alexander's design of leading them on to pass the ganges, too, which they were told was thirty-two furlongs broad and a fathom deep, and the banks on the further side covered with multitudes of enemies."}}</ref> 30,000<ref name="arrian 5.15">[[arrian]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=arr.+an.+5.15&fromdoc=perseus%3atext%3a2008.01.0530 5.15]</ref> or 50,000<ref name="diodorus 17.87.2">diodorus, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=perseus%3atext%3a1999.01.0084%3abook%3d17%3achapter%3d87%3asection%3d2 17.87.2]</ref> [[infantry]], <br>2,000<ref name=plutarch621/> to 4,000<ref name="arrian 5.15" /> [[cavalry]], <br>200,<ref name="arrian 5.15" /> 130<ref name="diodorus 17.87.2"/> ("likeliest" according to green),<ref>green, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ouf47it6_wgc&pg=pa553 p. 553]</ref> or 85<ref>curtius 8.13.6; ''metz epitome'' 54 (following curtius)</ref> [[war elephant]]s, <br>1,000 [[chariot]]s.<ref name=plutarch605>plutarch 60.5</ref>
infobox.casualties1: 80<ref name="arrian 5.18">arrian [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=arr.+an.+5.18&fromdoc=perseus%3atext%3a2008.01.0530 5.18]</ref> –700<ref name="diodorus 17.89.3" /><ref name = "fuller 199">according to fuller, pg 199, "diodorus' figures appear more realistic."</ref> infantry, <br> 230<ref name="arrian 5.18" />–280<ref name="diodorus 17.89.3" /> cavalry killed. modern estimates ≈1000 killed.{{sfn|roy|2004|pp=19–23}}
infobox.casualties2: 12,000 killed and 9,000 captured,<ref name="Diodorus 17.89.1-3" /> or 20,000 infantry and 3,000 cavalry killed.<ref name="Arrian 5.18" />
